Im pretty late to the game, though it released before I was born, but I gotta say this game holds true to the franchise. The story ark, about Black Mesa, the military, the Xen Invasion, it all connects. I suggest getting Blue Shift and Opposing Force to get the full story, if you are into that. If not, it's a very fun, lengthy retro game with sci-fi specs. The only annoying thing is when going down an elevator, there is a chance for you to get fused to the floor, but nothing too serious. Also.....WE ARE THE SCIENCE TEAM!!! 

P.S.- For Opposing Force and Blue Shift, if your mouse starts bugging out while you turn, all you gotta do is go to the settings and mark "Raw Mouse Input" and it should fix the error!

Half life is a great game, the gameplay is fun and fast without feeling unfair. Sometimes I would fail again and again, and then I got past it and felt great, while I admit I used god mode every once in a while when I had like 2 health (but you can judge me idc). Is the game perfect, god no. I could name off a couple problems but, overall, it's pretty good. Except the "HD" Models, don't use them, it's so bad.
Truly a fantastic game, Xen can be a bit of a slog but its worth it to see the ending and feel accomplished.

What do you want me to say? It's half life, one of the most influential and popular games of all time and for good reason. Most of this game is fast. frantic gun fights cut up with some puzzles and exploration. the only thing I wasn't a fan of is the last boss battle, it feels very cheap at times and I refuse to try and fight a gargantuan mid boss fight.

if you want a review on the classic hit shooter game Half-Life than you've come to the wrong place, instead, here's an outstanding pie recipe.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
